Reopening Schools Update

We understand the curiosity and anxiety that surrounds the unknown of how our students will return to school and we want to thank everyone for the support they have shown the members of our Reopening Schools Advisory team as we work through this together.

At this time, no decision has been made about how Sunnyside School District will open schools in August. Our Reopening Schools Advisory has done an incredible amount of work this summer to identify our options for bringing students back to school for face-to-face learning, and their input will be provided to the Sunnyside School District Board of Directors at the July 27 board meeting. It is up to the Board of Directors to approve our plans and from there we will communicate our plans for the fall out to the community.

Additionally, our plans are all subject to requirements from state and local agencies including the Governor, Office of the Superintendent of Public Instruction, Washington State Department of Health and the Yakima Health Department.

Sunnyside School District is pleased to announce that Dave Martinez has been selected as the new Athletic and Activities Director for the Sunnyside School District. Scott Paine, who previously held the position has taken the athletic director position for the Lake Chelan School District.

Martinez has been an assistant principal at Sunnyside High School for the past 12 years, and prior to that served as the Director of Supportive Learning during the closure of the school district's alternative school. He has taught English, and Diversified Occupations, Careers, and Leadership, has been the freshman and junior class advisor, and has coached football, and baseball.

"I am excited for this opportunity to focus solely on school culture," says Martinez. "The SHS staff and students have created an amazing culture unlike any other school. My plans are to continue to support this work and take it to the next level."

Three Sunnyside schools are being honored by the state for their success in closing gaps and helping students make gains.

Sierra Vista Middle School, Washington Elementary, and Chief Kamiakin Elementary have all been named State Recognized Schools for their work last school year.

They're among 391 schools in the state being highlighted by the Washington State Board of Education, the Office of Superintendent of Public Instruction and the Educational Opportunity Gap Oversight and Accountability Committee.

Sierra Vista Middle School is recognized for closing gaps for one or more student groups as a targeted support school. Washington Elementary achieved success in the area of growth for students who are English Language Learners and students identifying as white. And Chief Kamiakin, who also earned recognition last year, is recognized for closing gaps for all students.

Today is the last day to turn in ballots for the 2020 Levy. Ballots can be turned in at the drop box in the Sunnyside Post Office parking lot until 8 p.m. this evening.

Some things to remember about this levy:

This is not a new tax, it is a renewal of a tax that is already in place and was approved by Sunnyside residents in 2016.

Important programs, activities, and personnel are funded by local levy dollars including: security staff, nurses, and counselors, gang, drug, and alcohol prevention programs, middle and high school athletics, performing arts activities, both technology in the classroom and infrastructure, software, and Wifi systems.

Approval of the levy qualifies the District to receive an additional $8 million from the state of Washington at no cost to local taxpayers. The District will not receive this money if the levy fails.

Did you know "See Something, Say Something," is our district‚Äôs motto when it comes to student safety?

The hard part when asking students to report dangerous or suspicious activities of others, is their worry of being a tattle-tale or nark, reporting something that might turn out to be nothing, or the fear of getting someone in trouble.

To help with this, the SSD Tipline, available on all school websites and the District homepage, offers an anonymous option through phone, text, and email. School and District administers receive instant notification of a tip and are able to respond and ask additional questions through the system, while maintaining the tipsters anonymity. #SSDSAFETYWEEK2019

Did you know Sunnyside School District employs 6 security liaisons and a Security Specialist that work at Sunnyside High School, Harrison and Sierra Vista middle schools, and Outlook Elementary?

Each are CPR and First Aid certified. Each year, the liaisons attend the Washington School Safety Organization Conference, which provides professional development and safety training. Liaisons also receive DITEP or drug impairment training for education professionals, that enables them to recognize and evaluate individuals in a school setting who may be abusing or are under the influence of drugs, including alcohol and marijuana.

Our liaisons are Tyler Scherer (SVMS), Ignacio Tovar (SHS), Crystal Saucedo (HMS), Leo Gomez (SHS), Andy Carrizales (Outlook Elementary), Security Specialist Garin Moore, and Reese Paulus (SHS).

Volunteering in Sunnyside Schools

If you are interested in volunteering in Sunnyside schools, please take a few minutes to fill out our Volunteer Form:

English Version: http://bit.ly/2nWaQNg
Spanish Version: http://bit.ly/2mqyelA

This form includes authorization for a background check with the Washington State Patrol, which does not cost volunteers anything. It is also good for parents wanting to chaperone field/class trips.

Forms must be returned to the school office or the SSD District Office along with a copy of a current/valid photo id.

Once the application has been approved, which can take up to five days, you will receive a call from the SSD Family Engagement Office to come in for a photo and receive your Volunteer ID badge.

You can then contact your school of choice and volunteer!
